question.title: GridDB Java API bulk insert: why is put() 10× slower than documented performance benchmarks?
question.body:
I’m evaluating GridDB Community Edition 5.3 on macOS (running the Linux container in Docker Desktop) for a time-series IoT workload.
The official Performance Benchmarks white-paper claims ~140 k rows/sec for Java bulk inserts on similar hardware, but I’m seeing only 12–15 k rows/sec.

Environment

Item Value
OS macOS 14.4 (Apple M1)
Docker 24.0.7
GridDB CE 5.3.0
JDK Temurin 17.0.10
Java client griddb-client 5.3.0

Minimal reproducible example

import com.toshiba.mwcloud.gs.*;

public class BulkInsertTest {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        Properties props = new Properties();
        props.setProperty("notificationAddress","239.0.0.1");
        props.setProperty("notificationPort","31999");
        props.setProperty("clusterName","defaultCluster");
        props.setProperty("user","admin");
        props.setProperty("password","admin");
        GridStore store = GridStoreFactory.getInstance().getGridStore(props);

        // 1-column time-series container: timestamp + double
        ContainerInfo info = new ContainerInfo();
        info.setType(ContainerType.TIME_SERIES);
        info.setRowKeyAssigned(true);
        info.setColumnInfoList(List.of(
            new ColumnInfo("ts", GSType.TIMESTAMP),
            new ColumnInfo("value", GSType.DOUBLE)
        ));
        TimeSeries<Row> ts = store.putTimeSeries("sensor", info, true);

        final int TOTAL = 1_000_000;
        long start = System.nanoTime();
        for (int i = 0; i < TOTAL; i++) {
            Row r = ts.createRow();
            r.setTimestamp(0, new java.util.Date(1700000000000L + i*1000)); // +1 sec/row
            r.setDouble(1, Math.random());
            ts.put(r);                             //    <--  takes ~70 ms / 5 000 rows
            if (i % 5000 == 0) store.flush();      // tried explicit flush() too
        }
        store.flush();
        long elapsedMs = (System.nanoTime() - start)/1_000_000;
        System.out.printf("%,d rows in %d ms  (%.1f rows/sec)%n", 
                          TOTAL, elapsedMs, TOTAL*1000.0/elapsedMs);
    }
}

Environment

  • 1,000,000 rows in 79 231 ms (12 621 rows/sec)

What I’ve tried

  • Called store.flush() every 5 000 rows — no improvement
  • Disabled Docker volume sync (bind-mounted on local SSD)
  • Pre-allocated a pool of Row objects to reduce GC — marginal gain
  • Ran the bundled SampleBulkPut.java → same ~13 k rows/sec

Questions

  1. Is there a client-side batch or affinity setting (e.g., GS_BATCH_MODE) I need to enable?
  2. Do the published benchmarks rely on multiple parallel sessions? If so, what thread/session pattern is recommended?
  3. Are there Docker or JVM flags that materially improve single-node insert speed?
  4. Would using the C API or Python API yield higher single-thread throughput, or is the bottleneck in the server layer?

question_comments.body: At an instant glance, I'd just be suspicious of the standard failure modes of benchmarks, e.g. JIT and other things you have to worry about if you're not using JMH like a proper benchmark.
"on similar hardware" are they running also in macOS with Linux docker running everything in the same computer?
Don't make multiple questions in one. Questions should be specific and focused.
